title: Assignment 3: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
Week 3: Research Design

Finalize research questions and hypotheses
Select method approach and justify choice
Develop initial data collection protocol
Plan pilot study scope and procedures

title: Assignment 3: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
Week 4: Pilot Preparation

Set up tools, instruments, and access permissions
Create data collection materials (forms, templates, protocols)
Identify pilot test locations, subjects, or data sources
Conduct any necessary training or calibration

title: Assignment 3: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
Week 5: Pilot Execution and Refinement

Conduct pilot study and collect initial data
Evaluate pilot results and identify needed changes

Refine method protocol based on pilot learning
Submit A3 with pilot results and revised method plan


Remember: Your A3 test plan becomes the foundation for your A4 final analysis. Invest time in getting the method right ‚Äî good evidence comes from good methods, and good methods come from careful planning and pilot testing.

Research is iterative. Your pilot ‚Äúfailures‚Äù are actually methodological successes ‚Äî they help you design better studies and collect more reliable evidence.

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Due: End of Week 2
Weight: 15% of final grade
Length: 2-3 pages + 1 visual summary
Format: PDF submission via course portal

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Learning Objectives
By completing this assignment, you will:

Identify a suitable design object at an appropriate scale for evidence-based investigation
Frame a testable claim that can be evaluated with available data and methods
Define stakeholders who would benefit from evidence about your claim
Articulate the decision context where your evidence would be applied
Scope your investigation realistically within course constraints

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
section: Good Decision Claims Have Four Elements:
text:
Good Decision Claims Have Four Elements:

1. Design Object (What you‚Äôre investigating)

Specific enough to test systematically
Broad enough to generate useful evidence
Accessible for data collection within semester timeframe

Examples: - Window-to-wall ratios in Hong Kong residential towers - Ceiling height in collaborative workspaces
- Green roof configurations for urban buildings - Wayfinding signage systems in hospital environments


2. Performance Dimension (What you‚Äôre measuring)

Clearly defined and measurable
Connected to stakeholder concerns
Achievable with available tools and methods

Examples: - Energy performance, daylighting quality, thermal comfort - User satisfaction, space utilization, productivity metrics - Construction cost, maintenance requirements, lifecycle impact


3. Stakeholder Group (Who needs this evidence)

Specific decision-makers who would use your findings
Clear understanding of their constraints and priorities
Realistic access for validation and feedback

Examples: - Residential developers in dense urban markets - Corporate facility managers optimizing workplace design - Hospital administrators balancing patient outcomes and costs - Municipal planners developing green infrastructure policies


4. Decision Context (When/how evidence would be applied)

Real situations where choices must be made
Clear alternatives being compared
Specific decision criteria and trade-offs

Examples: - Early design phase when major systems are being selected - Retrofit decisions for existing building portfolios - Policy development requiring performance standards - Post-occupancy evaluation informing future projects

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Core Deliverables

Part 1: Problem Statement (1 page)
Write a clear, concise problem statement addressing:
Design Object Description - What specifically are you investigating? (Be precise about scale, typology, context) - Why is this object/system/space important in contemporary practice? - What design variables or alternatives will you focus on?
Current Decision-Making Process - How are decisions about this object typically made now? - What information do decision-makers currently use? - What gaps or uncertainties exist in current practice?
Proposed Claim - State your testable claim in one clear sentence - Explain why you believe this claim might be true (initial hypothesis) - Identify what evidence would support or refute your claim


Part 2: Stakeholder Analysis (1 page)
Identify and analyze your primary stakeholders:
Primary Decision-Makers - Who would directly use your evidence to make design decisions? - What are their main concerns, constraints, and success criteria? - How do they currently evaluate alternatives for your design object?
Secondary Stakeholders - Who else is affected by decisions about your design object? - What outcomes matter most to these groups? - How might their priorities conflict with primary decision-makers?
Evidence Requirements - What type of evidence would be most convincing to your stakeholders? - What level of precision/confidence would they require? - What format would make your findings most actionable for them?


Part 3: Scope and Constraints (0.5-1 page)
Realistically assess what you can accomplish this semester:
Available Resources - What data sources are accessible to you? - What tools and methods can you realistically learn and apply? - What time and budget constraints will shape your approach?
Manageable Scope - How will you narrow your investigation to be achievable? - What limitations will you acknowledge upfront? - What would constitute ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù for this project?


Part 4: Visual Summary (1 page)
Create a single-page visual that communicates: - Your design object with key variables highlighted - Your proposed claim as a testable question - Your primary stakeholders and their decision context - The type of evidence you plan to collect
This can be a diagram, infographic, or annotated photographs ‚Äî choose the format that best communicates your concept.

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Undergraduate Students

Focus: Clear problem identification with instructor guidance
Scope: Well-defined, smaller-scale objects (single building element or system)
Stakeholders: Primary focus on one main stakeholder group
Evidence: Straightforward metrics accessible through existing data or simple measurement

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
MArch Students

Focus: Professional memo format suitable for practice contexts
Scope: Building-scale or neighborhood-scale investigations
Stakeholders: Multiple stakeholder groups with competing priorities
Evidence: Industry-relevant metrics and decision criteria

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
PhD Students

Focus: Research question suitable for systematic investigation
Scope: Multi-building or policy-scale questions
Stakeholders: Complex stakeholder networks including regulatory bodies
Evidence: Methodologically rigorous approaches with uncertainty quantification

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Example 1: Residential Energy Performance
Design Object: Window-to-wall ratios in Hong Kong high-rise residential buildings
Claim: ‚ÄúOptimizing window-to-wall ratios can reduce residential cooling energy by 15-25% while maintaining acceptable daylighting levels‚Äù
Stakeholders: Residential developers, building owners, energy policy makers
Decision Context: Early design phase for new residential developments

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Example 2: Workplace Productivity
Design Object: Open office acoustics and spatial configuration
Claim: ‚ÄúStrategic placement of acoustic treatments can improve reported productivity by 20% without major space reallocation‚Äù
Stakeholders: Corporate facility managers, workplace designers, HR departments
Decision Context: Office renovation decisions and workplace strategy planning

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Example 3: Public Space Usage
Design Object: Seating arrangements in urban plazas
Claim: ‚ÄúFlexible seating configurations increase space utilization by 40% compared to fixed bench arrangements‚Äù
Stakeholders: Urban planners, park departments, public space designers
Decision Context: Public space design guidelines and renovation priorities

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Clarity and Feasibility (40%)

Clear problem definition: Is your design object specific and well-bounded?
Testable claim: Can your claim be evaluated with evidence?
Realistic scope: Is your investigation achievable within course constraints?

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Stakeholder Understanding (30%)

Relevant stakeholders: Have you identified appropriate decision-makers?
Decision context: Do you understand when/how your evidence would be used?
Evidence requirements: Do you know what would convince your stakeholders?

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Communication Quality (20%)

Professional presentation: Is your document clear, well-organized, and error-free?
Visual effectiveness: Does your visual summary communicate key concepts clearly?
Appropriate audience: Is your writing suitable for your intended stakeholders?

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Research Potential (10%)

Interesting question: Will investigating this claim generate useful knowledge?
Methodological feasibility: Can you reasonably collect relevant evidence?
Broader relevance: Could your findings inform similar decisions elsewhere?

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Scope Issues

Too broad: ‚ÄúHow to design sustainable buildings‚Äù (instead: focus on one specific system/element)
Too narrow: ‚ÄúThe optimal paint color for my bedroom‚Äù (instead: scale up to stakeholder relevance)
Too abstract: ‚ÄúHow to make beautiful architecture‚Äù (instead: focus on measurable performance)

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Claim Problems

Untestable: Claims about aesthetic preference or cultural meaning
Already proven: Well-established relationships documented in literature
Impossible to measure: Outcomes requiring unavailable data or methods

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Stakeholder Misalignment

No real stakeholders: Academic exercise without practical application
Unrealistic access: Stakeholders who won‚Äôt engage with student research
Mismatched priorities: Evidence that doesn‚Äôt address stakeholder concerns

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Week 1 Activities

Browse examples: Look at evidence-based design studies in journals and practice
Identify interests: What design decisions intrigue you? What performance questions do you have?
Talk to practitioners: What design decisions do working architects struggle with?
Check feasibility: What data and methods are realistically available to you?

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Resources for Topic Development

Building performance databases: Energy Star, LEED project database, local building surveys
User experience research: POE studies, occupant satisfaction surveys, space utilization data
Professional publications: Architectural Record, Journal of Green Building, Environment and Behavior
Local contexts: Hong Kong buildings, climate, regulations, and construction practices

title: Assignment 1: Decision Claim
text:
Getting Help

Office hours: Wednesdays 4-6pm at KB722, or by appointment
Peer discussion: Week 1 in-class workshop for topic development
Online forum: Course Slack for questions and idea sharing
Writing center: HKU academic support for clear technical writing


Remember: A strong Decision Claim sets up your entire semester project. Invest time in getting this foundation right ‚Äî it will make all subsequent assignments clearer and more focused.

This assignment launches your journey into evidence-based design thinking. Choose a question that genuinely interests you and matters to real decision-makers.
Code

Opening (5 minutes) - Slides 1-3
Energy: Start high, acknowledge the holiday make-up session
Key Message: ‚ÄúToday we‚Äôre going to solve the biggest problem I saw in your A1 assignments - the gap between talking about stakeholders and actually engaging them.‚Äù
Speaker Notes: - Mention you‚Äôve finished grading A1 - overall excellent technical thinking - But almost everyone struggled with the same thing: stakeholder specificity - Today is about bridging that gap for A3 - Keep energy high since it‚Äôs a make-up session
Timing: Keep intro brief, students want to dive in

A2 Gallery Walk (10 minutes) - Slide 4
Format: Quick stand-up presentations (2-3 minutes each) Your role: Listen for stakeholder gaps, note patterns
What to listen for and call out: - Who mentioned specific people vs.¬†categories? - Who has actual contact plans vs.¬†vague intentions? - Where do technical findings connect to stakeholder priorities?
Transition: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hearing great technical insights, but let‚Äôs talk about what I noticed in A1‚Ä¶‚Äù

section: The Stakeholder Reality Check (15 minutes) - Slides 5-11
text:
The Stakeholder Reality Check (15 minutes) - Slides 5-11

Slide 5: What We Observed in A1 (3 minutes)
Be direct but encouraging: - ‚ÄúYour technical thinking was strong - that‚Äôs not the issue‚Äù - ‚ÄúThe gap is in moving from ‚Äòcommunity engagement‚Äô as a buzzword to actual community engagement as a research method‚Äù - Use specific examples from their submissions (anonymized)
Energy: Constructive but frank - they need to hear this


Slide 6: The Community Engagement Trap (4 minutes)
Present this as a pattern, not a specific story: - Frame it as a common pattern you see repeatedly in practice - Reference actual research: ‚ÄúPost-occupancy evaluation studies show this pattern‚Äù - Pause after describing the workshops: ‚ÄúSound familiar?‚Äù - Emphasize the key point: asking WHAT they want vs.¬†HOW they‚Äôll know it works - Connect to their studio projects: ‚ÄúHow many of you have done this?‚Äù
Audience engagement: Ask for show of hands on who has community engagement in their brief
Factual backing: You can reference actual POE literature that documents this pattern - Wolfgang Preiser‚Äôs work on facility performance evaluation consistently shows this gap.


Slide 7: Studio Projects vs.¬†Real Stakeholders (3 minutes)
Make this interactive: - Ask them to read their brief language out loud - Have them answer the bullet point questions about their actual project - Most will realize they don‚Äôt have good answers - that‚Äôs the point


Slides 8-11: Stakeholder Mapping (5 minutes)
Keep this practical: - Have them think about their specific project while you explain - Use the Hong Kong office tower example - everyone can relate to view vs.¬†comfort - Emphasize that this isn‚Äôt just consultation - it‚Äôs research methodology

Metrics That Matter (10 minutes) - Slides 12-16

Slide 12: The Measurement Problem (2 minutes)
Be specific: Call out actual language from A1 submissions - ‚ÄúI saw variations of these exact phrases in your assignments‚Äù - ‚ÄúThe problem isn‚Äôt that you don‚Äôt care about measurement - it‚Äôs that you haven‚Äôt connected measurement to stakeholder priorities‚Äù


Slides 13-14: Types of Metrics & Examples (4 minutes)
Use the library example actively: - Walk through each metric type - Ask: ‚ÄúWho cares about which metric?‚Äù - Point out how different stakeholders would prioritize differently


Slide 15: Metrics You Can Actually Measure (4 minutes)
Be practical: - ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not writing a PhD dissertation - you need semester-feasible approaches‚Äù - Connect each category to their likely projects - Emphasize observation and surveys as most accessible

Understanding Sensitivity (8 minutes) - Slides 17-21

Slide 17: What is Sensitivity Analysis (2 minutes)
Frame the shift: - Traditional sensitivity = technical - Stakeholder sensitivity = social/political - Both matter for real-world implementation


Slides 18-19: Types & Example (4 minutes)
Use the window example actively: - Start with technical questions they‚Äôd normally ask - Then add stakeholder dimension - Show how the same technical data leads to different conclusions


Slide 20: The View vs.¬†Comfort Dilemma (2 minutes)
Tell this as a story: - Set up the technical findings first - Then reveal the stakeholder complexity - Ask: ‚ÄúWho wins? How do you decide?‚Äù - Connect to their projects: ‚ÄúWhere do you have similar conflicts?‚Äù

Community Engagement Planning (8 minutes) - Slides 22-25

Slide 22: The Engagement Spectrum (2 minutes)
Be diagnostic: - ‚ÄúMost projects start at Information Sharing‚Äù - ‚ÄúMost think they‚Äôre at Consultation‚Äù - ‚ÄúEvidence-based projects need Collaboration‚Äù - Ask them to self-assess their current approach


Slide 23: The 5-Question Framework (3 minutes)
Make this a mini-exercise: - Have them answer question 1 about their project right now - Most can‚Äôt name specific people - that‚Äôs the learning moment - ‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt answer question 1, you‚Äôre not ready for evidence collection‚Äù


Slide 24: Practical Engagement for A3 (3 minutes)
Connect to their timeline: - ‚ÄúThis is what you should be doing in the next 2 weeks‚Äù - Be specific about 3-5 interviews, not dozens - Emphasize documentation and iteration

Peer Review Workshop (10 minutes) - Slides 26-30

Setup (2 minutes)
Be clear about the new structure: - Traditional peer review + stakeholder accountability - Phase 2 is the new element focused on their A1 gaps - Partners should be constructively critical


Phase 1: Method Exchange (3 minutes)
Your role: Move around, listen for stakeholder gaps, prompt questions


Phase 2: Stakeholder Reality Check (3 minutes)
Your role: Jump in when you hear vague answers, push for specificity - ‚ÄúWhen you say ‚Äòcommunity‚Äô - who exactly?‚Äù - ‚ÄúHow will you know if they‚Äôre satisfied?‚Äù


Phase 3: Critical Feedback (2 minutes)
Traditional peer review focus

Wrap-up & Looking Ahead (4 minutes) - Slides 31-32

Key Takeaways (2 minutes)
Emphasize the shift: - From technical-focused to stakeholder-engaged evidence - From consultation to collaboration - From vague metrics to specific measurement


Questions & Discussion (2 minutes)
Target the new content: - Focus questions on stakeholder engagement planning - Ask for specific commitments: ‚ÄúWho will you interview this week?‚Äù

Timing Notes
If running ahead: - Spend more time on the engagement planning exercise - Have students work through the 5-question framework for their project - Do more detailed peer review rounds
If running behind: - Combine slides 8-11 into shorter stakeholder mapping overview - Reduce peer review to just the stakeholder reality check phase - Focus Q&A on immediate A3 planning needs
Energy management: - Break after slide 16 if energy dips (around 35 minutes) - Use the case studies as energy boosters - tell them as stories - Keep students engaged with direct questions about their projects

Key Examples to Emphasize

The Community Engagement Pattern (Slide 6) - Shows the gap between consultation and collaboration
Hong Kong Office Tower (Slide 20) - Demonstrates stakeholder vs.¬†technical conflicts
Daylighting Case Study (Slides 31-32) - Shows how multiple stakeholders complicate ‚Äúsimple‚Äù technical decisions

Delivery tips: - Present as recognizable patterns, not specific stories unless you have verified details - Use research-backed examples (POE studies, published case studies) - Connect each back to their studio projects - Ask ‚ÄúDoes this sound familiar?‚Äù after each one - For the HK office tower example, you can make it more specific since this is a common local scenario

Common Student Questions & Responses
Q: ‚ÄúMy studio brief already includes community engagement requirements‚Äù A: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great - but does it specify HOW you‚Äôll measure successful engagement? Most briefs say ‚Äòengage‚Äô but don‚Äôt define what evidence would show you succeeded.‚Äù
Q: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have access to real stakeholders for my studio project‚Äù A: ‚ÄúThen your A3 should acknowledge that limitation and focus on what you CAN measure. But you‚Äôd be surprised - most ‚Äòinaccessible‚Äô stakeholders are actually reachable if you‚Äôre specific about what you‚Äôre asking.‚Äù
Q: ‚ÄúHow many people do I need to interview?‚Äù A: ‚ÄúQuality over quantity. 3-5 targeted interviews with the right people beats 20 random surveys. Focus on stakeholders who actually influence decisions about your design object.‚Äù
Q: ‚ÄúWhat if my stakeholders disagree about success metrics?‚Äù A: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs exactly what your research should uncover! Document the disagreement - it‚Äôs often more valuable than consensus. Show how design decisions affect different groups differently.‚Äù

Post-Class Follow-up
Send within 24 hours: - Reminder about A3 pilot study timeline - Link to stakeholder engagement resources - Template for the 5-question framework - Office hours reminder for A3 planning
Key message: ‚ÄúStart with stakeholder identification this week - everything else flows from there.‚Äù

text:
üíÄ When Good Research Goes Bad (Story Edition)
Before we become storytelling champions, let‚Äôs learn from the narrative graveyard‚Ä¶



Real-World Presentation Disasters


üè¢ Case 1: The $50M Miscommunication

PhD researcher presents brilliant energy analysis to Hong Kong developer board
45 minutes of technical methodology explanation
30 seconds on what this means for their bottom line
Board‚Äôs response: ‚ÄúInteresting‚Ä¶ but what should we actually DO?‚Äù
Result: No adoption, project shelved, researcher never invited back

üìä Case 2: The Chart Catastrophe

Consultant shows 47 different charts to planning committee
Every chart technically perfect, statistically sound
No chart tells decision-makers what action to take
Committee response: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre more confused than when we started‚Äù
Result: Status quo wins, innovative solution dies




ü§î Reality Check: How many of your presentations focus more on HOW you did it than WHY anyone should care?

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
text:
Generative Design is not Magic


It‚Äôs about making design decisions with evidence ‚Äî data, simulations, and thresholds.


Students often think ‚Äúgenerative‚Äù = black-box AI magic. Clarify from the start: this course is about reproducibility, clarity, and decision usefulness.

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
text:
Case 1 ‚Äì Apple Park Glass Walls
Employees at Apple Park kept walking into the pristine curved glass walls.

NYT (2018) reported multiple incidents. A design that looked flawless in renders failed human factors testing.
If the object is ‚Äútransparent fa√ßade,‚Äù a decision claim might be: ‚ÄúDoes a subtle coating reduce accidents without losing daylight?‚Äù

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
section: Case 2 ‚Äì Daylight as a Design Asset
text:
Case 2 ‚Äì Daylight as a Design Asset

WELL Building Standard pushes daylight for health. Tech firms compete for daylight-rich workspaces.

Wired & Architectural Digest covered how big firms prioritize daylight to boost productivity and health.
Evidence links daylight exposure to sleep and wellbeing.
Prompt: ‚ÄúIf your object is window size, how do you test daylight vs.¬†glare trade-offs?‚Äù

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
text:
Case 3 ‚Äì Heat Resilience in Cities
Paris 2022: heatwaves forced rethink of shade, airflow, and public space.

Architectural press documented how shade structures and surface materials affect thermal comfort.
Evidence can guide claims like: ‚ÄúDoes increasing tree cover by 20% reduce perceived heat stress?‚Äù

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
text:
Case 4 ‚Äì AI Hype vs.¬†Evidence

Generative AI renders go viral ‚Äî but few are tested for buildability.

Dezeen and WIRED highlight seductive AI-generated architecture images.
But are they ventilated? Do they meet comfort codes?
Prompt: ‚ÄúIf your object is an AI render, what evidence claim would you test first?‚Äù

title: Week 1: Why Evidence Matters
text:
Case 5 ‚Äì Energy Retrofits as Evidence

NYC Local Law 97 sets strict emission thresholds for buildings.

Architectural Record covered how retrofits must now meet numeric CO‚ÇÇ caps.
Policy itself provides evidence: thresholds like ‚â§ 0.9 W/m¬≤K for adoption.
Ask students: ‚ÄúIf your object is insulation, what‚Äôs your adopt/defer threshold?‚Äù

title: ARCH7476: Evidence-Based Generative Design
text:
ARCH7476: Evidence-Based Generative Design explores how architects can make better design decisions through systematic data collection, analysis, and interpretation. This course bridges the gap between intuitive design thinking and empirical evidence, preparing students to justify design choices with quantitative and qualitative data.



‚ÄúGenerative design is not magic‚Äù ‚Äî it requires evidence, testing, and systematic evaluation.

Modern architectural practice increasingly demands evidence-based decision making. Whether optimizing building performance, validating design assumptions, or communicating with clients and stakeholders, architects need skills in data collection, analysis, and presentation.



By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Frame architectural problems as testable research questions
Collect and analyze data relevant to design decisions
Design and conduct tests to evaluate design alternatives
Communicate findings effectively to diverse audiences
Document workflows for reproducible design research
Apply ethical frameworks to data collection and use in architecture




This course serves students across different programs:

MArch students: Focus on practical design decision memos and real-world applications
Undergraduate students: Guided scaffolding with low-code tools and preset simulations
PhD students: Deeper engagement with uncertainty analysis, reproducibility, and advanced workflows

All students produce equivalent deliverables, but technical depth and methodological rigor flex according to experience and program requirements.

title: ARCH7476: Evidence-Based Generative Design
text:
Course Structure

Core Assignments
The course centers around four major assignments that build toward a comprehensive research brief:

A1: Decision Claim (Week 2)

Identify a design object and articulate a testable claim about its performance or impact.

A2: Evidence Map (Week 4)

Map existing evidence and identify gaps requiring new data collection.

A3: Test Plan + Pilot (Week 5)

Design and pilot a systematic test of your design claim.

A4: Final Package (Week 12)

Complete research brief including Practice Case, Object Card, and Reproducibility Capsule.




Pedagogical Approach

Learning by doing: Each week combines conceptual frameworks with hands-on application
Peer review: Multiple opportunities for peer feedback and collaborative learning
Mentor dialogue: Mid-course consultation with external practitioners
Public presentation: Final ‚ÄúObject Fair‚Äù with invited critics



Tools and Technology
The course emphasizes tool flexibility rather than software mastery:
Low-code options: Excel/Sheets, QGIS, preset simulations (Radiance/VELUX, EnergyPlus Simple Glazing)
Code-heavy options: Python/Colab, GitHub workflows, custom analysis scripts
Universal tools: Visualization software, presentation platforms, documentation systems

title: Python + ML Basics for Architects
text:
A fast, friendly introduction to Python, data handling, and simple machine learning ‚Äî using fake but architecture-flavored data.
Goals: - Learn Python + pandas basics - Load and explore a dataset about windows/daylight/energy - Split into train/test, fit simple models, and evaluate - Understand cross-validation and overfitting with visuals - Get a small taste of neural nets via an MLP (‚Äúdeep learning vibe‚Äù)


If you are on a fresh environment, you may need to install packages (run one by one if needed):
# !pip install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn scikit-learn scipy wordcloud
This notebook expects the repository structure with a data/ and scripts/ folder.

from pathlib import Path
import sys, warnings

# Add repo root and scripts to import path when running from notebooks/
if '__file__' in globals():
    ROOT = Path(__file__).resolve().parents[1]
else:
    candidate = Path.cwd()
    if (candidate / 'scripts').exists():
        ROOT = candidate
    elif candidate.name == 'notebooks' and (candidate.parent / 'scripts').exists():
        ROOT = candidate.parent
    else:
        ROOT = candidate
if str(ROOT / 'scripts') not in sys.path:
    sys.path.append(str(ROOT / 'scripts'))

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split, KFold, cross_val_score
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, PolynomialFeatures
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression, Ridge
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score, mean_absolute_error
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, confusion_matrix
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPClassifier

from plotting_utils import set_style, plot_cv_folds, confusion_matrix_plot, learning_curve_plot, validation_curve_plot
import data_simulation as sim

set_style()
np.random.seed(42)




Python stores numbers, strings, lists, and dictionaries. You‚Äôll mostly use lists/dicts and then pandas DataFrames.

# Lists and dicts
sizes = [10, 20, 30]
room = {"name": "Studio A", "area_m2": 120, "seats": 40}
sizes.append(40)
{"sizes": sizes, "room": room}


# Numpy and pandas basics
import numpy as np, pandas as pd
a = np.array([1,2,3])
df = pd.DataFrame({"x": [1,2,3], "y": [3,2,1]})
df.describe()




We use fake data that mimics window-to-wall ratio (wwr), shading depth, orientation, and energy/daylight outcomes.

data_path = ROOT / 'data' / 'building_performance_fake.csv'
if not data_path.exists():
    # Generate defaults if missing
    sim.save_default_fake_data(ROOT)

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)
df.head()


df.describe(include='all')


sns.pairplot(df[['wwr','shading_depth_m','daylit_area','glare_probability','cooling_kwh_m2']])
plt.suptitle('Quick relationships', y=1.02);




We fit a simple linear model and evaluate on a held-out test set.

features = ['wwr','shading_depth_m','orientation','glazing_u_w_m2k']
target = 'cooling_kwh_m2'
X = df[features]
y = df[target]

cat = ['orientation']
num = ['wwr','shading_depth_m','glazing_u_w_m2k']
pre = ColumnTransformer([
    ("cat", OneHotEncoder(drop='first'), cat),
    ("num", 'passthrough', num)
])

X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.25, random_state=42)
reg = Pipeline([('pre', pre), ('model', LinearRegression())])
reg.fit(X_train, y_train)
pred = reg.predict(X_test)
r2 = r2_score(y_test, pred)
mae = mean_absolute_error(y_test, pred)
r2, mae


plt.scatter(y_test, pred, alpha=0.8)
plt.xlabel('Actual cooling kWh/m¬≤')
plt.ylabel('Predicted')
plt.title(f'Linear Regression: R¬≤={r2:.2f}, MAE={mae:.1f}')
m = np.array([y_test.min(), y_test.max()])
plt.plot(m, m, 'k--', alpha=0.5)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()




Define a simple label: comfortable if glare_probability < 0.35 and daylit_area > 0.5.

df['comfortable'] = ((df['glare_probability'] < 0.35) & (df['daylit_area'] > 0.5)).astype(int)
Xc = df[['wwr','shading_depth_m','orientation']]
yc = df['comfortable']
pre_c = ColumnTransformer([
    ("cat", OneHotEncoder(drop='first'), ['orientation']),
    ("num", 'passthrough', ['wwr','shading_depth_m'])
])
Xtr, Xte, ytr, yte = train_test_split(Xc, yc, test_size=0.25, random_state=42, stratify=yc)
clf = Pipeline([('pre', pre_c), ('model', LogisticRegression(max_iter=1000))])
clf.fit(Xtr, ytr)
predc = clf.predict(Xte)
acc = accuracy_score(yte, predc)
cm = confusion_matrix(yte, predc)
acc, cm


confusion_matrix_plot(cm, class_names=("Not Comfortable","Comfortable"), title=f'Logistic Regression (Accuracy={acc:.2f})');




We vary model complexity (polynomial degree) and show CV scores.

deg_scores = []
cv = KFold(n_splits=5, shuffle=True, random_state=42)
for deg in range(1,7):
    poly = PolynomialFeatures(degree=deg, include_bias=False)
    pipe = Pipeline([('pre', pre), ('poly', poly), ('ridge', Ridge(alpha=1.0))])
    scores = cross_val_score(pipe, X, y, cv=cv, scoring='r2')
    deg_scores.append((deg, scores.mean(), scores.std()))

ds = pd.DataFrame(deg_scores, columns=['degree','cv_mean','cv_std'])
plt.errorbar(ds['degree'], ds['cv_mean'], yerr=ds['cv_std'], fmt='o-')
plt.xlabel('Polynomial degree (complexity)')
plt.ylabel('CV R¬≤')
plt.title('Overfitting demo: watch CV score peak then drop')
plt.tight_layout(); plt.show()
ds



Each row is a fold; green cells are train, red cells are test.

cv2 = KFold(n_splits=5, shuffle=True, random_state=7)
_ = plot_cv_folds(n_samples=len(X), cv_splits=cv2.split(np.arange(len(X))), title='5-fold CV: train vs test membership')
plt.show()





A small neural network classifier. This is just to build intuition ‚Äî it‚Äôs not magic, and simple models are often enough.

mlp = Pipeline([('pre', pre_c), ('mlp', MLPClassifier(hidden_layer_sizes=(16,8), max_iter=1000, random_state=42))])
mlp.fit(Xtr, ytr)
acc_mlp = accuracy_score(yte, mlp.predict(Xte))
acc, acc_mlp



How performance improves with more data.

_ = learning_curve_plot(clf, Xc, yc, cv=5, scoring='accuracy')
plt.show()






Always hold out test data or use cross-validation
Start simple; only add complexity if it improves validated performance
Document random seeds and settings for reproducibility
‚ÄúDeep‚Äù models need more data and care; don‚Äôt overfit

Next: a richer notebook focused on visualizing pilot results and making figures for stakeholders.

y = df[target]

cat = ['orientation']
num = ['wwr','shading_depth_m','glazing_u_w_m2k']
pre = ColumnTransformer([
    ("cat", OneHotEncoder(drop='first'), cat),
    ("num", 'passthrough', num)
])

X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.25, random_state=42)
reg = Pipeline([('pre', pre), ('model', LinearRegression())])
reg.fit(X_train, y_train)
pred = reg.predict(X_test)
r2 = r2_score(y_test, pred)
mae = mean_absolute_error(y_test, pred)
r2, mae


plt.scatter(y_test, pred, alpha=0.8)
plt.xlabel('Actual cooling kWh/m¬≤')
plt.ylabel('Predicted')
plt.title(f'Linear Regression: R¬≤={r2:.2f}, MAE={mae:.1f}')
m = np.array([y_test.min(), y_test.max()])
plt.plot(m, m, 'k--', alpha=0.5)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

title: Python + ML Basics for Architects
text:
Define a simple label: comfortable if glare_probability < 0.35 and daylit_area > 0.5.

df['comfortable'] = ((df['glare_probability'] < 0.35) & (df['daylit_area'] > 0.5)).astype(int)
Xc = df[['wwr','shading_depth_m','orientation']]
yc = df['comfortable']
pre_c = ColumnTransformer([
    ("cat", OneHotEncoder(drop='first'), ['orientation']),
    ("num", 'passthrough', ['wwr','shading_depth_m'])
])
Xtr, Xte, ytr, yte = train_test_split(Xc, yc, test_size=0.25, random_state=42, stratify=yc)
clf = Pipeline([('pre', pre_c), ('model', LogisticRegression(max_iter=1000))])
clf.fit(Xtr, ytr)
predc = clf.predict(Xte)
acc = accuracy_score(yte, predc)
cm = confusion_matrix(yte, predc)
acc, cm


confusion_matrix_plot(cm, class_names=("Not Comfortable","Comfortable"), title=f'Logistic Regression (Accuracy={acc:.2f})');

title: Python + ML Basics for Architects
text:
We vary model complexity (polynomial degree) and show CV scores.

deg_scores = []
cv = KFold(n_splits=5, shuffle=True, random_state=42)
for deg in range(1,7):
    poly = PolynomialFeatures(degree=deg, include_bias=False)
    pipe = Pipeline([('pre', pre), ('poly', poly), ('ridge', Ridge(alpha=1.0))])
    scores = cross_val_score(pipe, X, y, cv=cv, scoring='r2')
    deg_scores.append((deg, scores.mean(), scores.std()))

ds = pd.DataFrame(deg_scores, columns=['degree','cv_mean','cv_std'])
plt.errorbar(ds['degree'], ds['cv_mean'], yerr=ds['cv_std'], fmt='o-')
plt.xlabel('Polynomial degree (complexity)')
plt.ylabel('CV R¬≤')
plt.title('Overfitting demo: watch CV score peak then drop')
plt.tight_layout(); plt.show()
ds



Each row is a fold; green cells are train, red cells are test.

cv2 = KFold(n_splits=5, shuffle=True, random_state=7)
_ = plot_cv_folds(n_samples=len(X), cv_splits=cv2.split(np.arange(len(X))), title='5-fold CV: train vs test membership')
plt.show()

title: Python + ML Basics for Architects
text:
A small neural network classifier. This is just to build intuition ‚Äî it‚Äôs not magic, and simple models are often enough.

mlp = Pipeline([('pre', pre_c), ('mlp', MLPClassifier(hidden_layer_sizes=(16,8), max_iter=1000, random_state=42))])
mlp.fit(Xtr, ytr)
acc_mlp = accuracy_score(yte, mlp.predict(Xte))
acc, acc_mlp



How performance improves with more data.

_ = learning_curve_plot(clf, Xc, yc, cv=5, scoring='accuracy')
plt.show()

title: Python + ML Basics for Architects
text:
Always hold out test data or use cross-validation
Start simple; only add complexity if it improves validated performance
Document random seeds and settings for reproducibility
‚ÄúDeep‚Äù models need more data and care; don‚Äôt overfit

Next: a richer notebook focused on visualizing pilot results and making figures for stakeholders.

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
This document provides detailed feedback for each student‚Äôs A3 submission based on the established grading criteria:

Research Design Quality (40%)
Pilot Study Execution (30%)
Method Documentation (20%)
Communication Quality (10%)

Each assessment follows the requested format: opening acknowledgment, core critique with ranked strengths/weaknesses, and unique developmental closing comment.

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
2.1 1. Tsz Ho Chan

2.1.1 Opening Recognition
Your A3 submission demonstrates sophisticated understanding of LLM-agent simulation methodology and shows excellent integration of computational modeling with human validation approaches.


2.1.2 Core Assessment
Research Design Quality (40%)
Strengths (Ranked by Impact): - ‚úÖ Clear quantitative success criteria: Jaccard ‚â• 0.6 and stress reduction ‚â• 15% provide specific, measurable thresholds - ‚úÖ Well-justified hybrid methodology: Combines simulation study, comparative analysis, and user validation effectively - ‚úÖ Systematic data collection protocol: 1m grid cells, identical seeds, controlled runtime parameters ensure reproducibility
Areas for Improvement (Ranked by Severity): - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Sample size justification missing - convenience sample of 8-12 participants insufficient for reliable statistical analysis - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Limited discussion of LLM agent calibration parameters for privacy sensitivity modeling - üìù MINOR: Competing explanations could be more systematically structured for testing
Pilot Study Execution (30%)
Strengths: - ‚úÖ Systematic refinement approach: Clear documentation of seed consistency issues and visibility proxy improvements - ‚úÖ Realistic time estimates: 1.5h setup, 20min runs, detailed breakdown supports feasibility - ‚úÖ Problem identification and solutions: Issues with rater attention and export timestamps clearly documented
Areas for Improvement: - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Pilot appears synthetic/illustrative rather than actual human validation testing - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Missing concrete results from pilot - no actual Jaccard scores or stress metrics reported - üìù MINOR: Rater attention solutions could be more specific beyond ‚Äúattention checks‚Äù
Method Documentation (20%)
Strengths: - ‚úÖ Clear step-by-step protocol: 7-step process with specific parameters and decision criteria - ‚úÖ Reproducibility considerations: GitHub repository, file hashing, version control mentioned - ‚úÖ Data organization structure: Clear directory structure and naming conventions
Areas for Improvement: - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Ethical considerations minimal - consent procedures inadequately specified - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Quality control procedures for data validation need more detail - üìù MINOR: GitHub repository access unclear (‚Äúavailable upon request‚Äù)
Communication Quality (10%)
Strengths: - ‚úÖ Clear technical communication: Complex methodology explained accessibly - ‚úÖ Logical structure: Good flow from research questions through pilot to refinement - ‚úÖ Professional formatting: Clean organization with appropriate headings
Areas for Improvement: - ‚ùå CRITICAL: No visual aids despite references to ‚Äúfour-panel visuals‚Äù and heatmaps - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Some formatting artifacts from PDF conversion affect readability - üìù MINOR: Figure captions could be more descriptive of actual content


2.1.3 Developmental Closing
Your computational approach to residential layout assessment represents innovative thinking that could significantly advance evidence-based housing design methodology.
Estimated Grade: B+ (78/100)

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
2.2 2. Sze Wai Ma (Wendy)

2.2.1 Opening Recognition
Your A3 submission demonstrates exceptional awareness of social equity issues in Tin Shui Wai and shows sophisticated integration of biophilic design principles with community-centered research methodology.


2.2.2 Core Assessment
Research Design Quality (40%)
Strengths (Ranked by Impact): - ‚úÖ Outstanding contextual relevance: Direct engagement with TSW‚Äôs ‚ÄúCity of Sadness‚Äù narrative and elderly/caregiver needs - ‚úÖ Sophisticated hypothesis structure: H1 (greenspace), H2 (affective design), H3 (social equity) comprehensively address research gaps - ‚úÖ Methodologically rigorous approach: Mixed-methods design with clear quantitative and qualitative components
Areas for Improvement (Ranked by Severity): - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Statistical analysis plan lacks specificity - t-test assumptions and effect size calculations missing - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Control site selection criteria need more detailed justification - üìù MINOR: ‚ÄúReal-time demand signals‚Äù concept could be more clearly operationalized
Pilot Study Execution (30%)
Strengths: - ‚úÖ Excellent cultural adaptation: Academic language refined based on pilot (‚ÄúAffective Sense of Place‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúWhat makes this feel like your place?‚Äù) - ‚úÖ Systematic learning integration: Observation intervals changed from 15-min to 5-min cycles based on pilot findings - ‚úÖ Professional ethical awareness: Clear attention to caregiver definition and inter-rater reliability
Areas for Improvement: - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Limited quantitative pilot results reported - missing actual usage counts or satisfaction scores - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Small pilot scale (1 hour, 1 site) limits confidence in method refinements - üìù MINOR: Inter-rater reliability training procedures could be more detailed
Method Documentation (20%)
Strengths: - ‚úÖ Exceptionally detailed protocol: Clear operational definitions (e.g., ‚ÄúCaregiver‚Äù vs ‚ÄúParent‚Äù) - ‚úÖ Strong ethical framework: Appropriate consent procedures for vulnerable populations - ‚úÖ Comprehensive scope planning: Addresses governance/tenure fragmentation contextually
Areas for Improvement: - ‚ùå CRITICAL: Data analysis software and specific statistical procedures not specified - ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Sample data collection forms not included despite mention - üìù MINOR: Timeline details could include contingency planning

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
3.1 Overall Performance Distribution
Grade Distribution: - A- (85-89): 1 student (Sze Wai Ma) - B+ (78-82): 3 students (Tsz Ho Chan, Wing Tung Lee, Wing Sum Leung) - B (75-79): 3 students (Man Lap Martin Dun, Ye Yan, Anyi Lyu) - B- (70-74): 1 student (Lee Chun Chow) - C+ (69-73): 6 students (remaining)
Class Average: ~75% (B-)

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
3.2 Common Strengths Observed
Methodological Innovation: - Students demonstrated creative adaptation of research methods to architectural contexts - Strong technical competence in computational modeling and simulation approaches - Good understanding of systematic research design principles
Professional Development: - Evidence of serious engagement with evidence-based design methodology - Integration of course concepts with individual research interests - Realistic assessment of practical constraints and implementation challenges
Learning Integration: - Clear progression building on A1 and A2 foundations - Good use of pilot testing concept to refine and improve methods - Honest documentation of challenges and adaptive problem-solving

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
3.3 Critical Areas for Development
Pilot Study Execution (Most Common Weakness): - Many pilots were illustrative/synthetic rather than actual testing - Limited quantitative results reported from pilot implementations - Insufficient sample sizes for reliable statistical conclusions - Missing validation of computational methods against real-world data
Ethical Considerations (Significant Gap): - Minimal attention to consent procedures for human subjects research - Inadequate consideration of vulnerable populations (elderly, community interviews) - Missing institutional review considerations for interview-based studies - Need for better privacy and safety protocols
Success Criteria Specificity (Methodological Issue): - Many studies lacked specific, measurable success thresholds - Vague criteria like ‚Äúimproved performance‚Äù without quantification - Missing statistical power calculations for sample size determination - Insufficient consideration of stakeholder decision-making needs
Visual Documentation (Communication Gap): - Almost universal lack of visual aids, diagrams, or supporting graphics - Missing documentation of spatial layouts, design alternatives, or results - Poor integration of technical analysis with visual communication - Inadequate consideration of presentation to non-technical stakeholders

title: A3 Assessment: Test Plan + Pilot Study
text:
3.4 Recommendations for A4 Success
Focus on Stakeholder Validation: - Prioritize human validation over computational metrics alone - Develop specific, measurable criteria that stakeholders can understand - Include actual user testing rather than theoretical predictions - Connect technical results to real-world decision-making contexts
Strengthen Ethical Framework: - Develop proper consent procedures for all human subjects research - Consider IRB approval for interview-based studies - Address privacy and safety concerns systematically - Plan for vulnerable population considerations
Improve Visual Communication: - Include diagrams, charts, and visual documentation of methods - Develop clear before/after comparisons for design interventions - Create stakeholder-friendly presentations of technical results - Use visual aids to support technical explanations
Enhance Reproducibility: - Provide sufficient detail for independent replication - Include specific software versions, settings, and parameters - Document quality control and validation procedures - Create templates and checklists for data collection
